page.title: 11Hurdle making
page.content: Hurdle making is an ancient art.In our area the number of hurdle makers has dwindled down to {three}.The art is usually passed down the line from generation to generation.At{7:00 a.m. {Mr Lockyear}would go to the wood if weather permits it.He begins by plac- ing{9}ready cut{sails}into a{wooden} frame.These sails are{hazel or maple} uprights and the frame is a wooden pole with{9}holes drilled in it. He then begins weaving thin rods of wood in and out between the sails.This is called{bottoming.}Any extra length is twisted until the bark breaks and then is woven back through the sails. To achieve a pattern he splits the rods in half and so has a dark and a light side. A contractor buys most of what he makes.The hurdles,which sell for {Â£1.50/ft,are often used for fencing. {AUTHORS:S.O'Keefe,C.S-Smith,C.Tyrrell
